model.socialDescription: Light a fire, throw some steaks on the stone and make some s'mores cookies.
model.section1Hed: A Steak Feast by the Fire
model.dek: Just because you're on the trail doesn't mean you should survive on trail mix.
model.section2Dek: Because what would camping be without s'mores (or s'mores cookies) and a flask of something smoky?
model.section3Dek: Make-ahead hobo packs mean an unforgettable hot breakfast, complete with runny eggs.

section3List.hed: How to Make a Hobo Pack Breakfast
section3List.dek: Because you don't *really* want granola bars and bananas when you wake up in a tent.
section3List.promoHed: How to Make a Hobo Pack Breakfast
section3List.body:
When you think about it, camping is a lot like staying at a hotel. You're sleeping in an unfamiliar place. You don't have all the comforts of home. And sometimes, all you get in the morning is a cold muffin and a carton of juice.

Is that the kind of breakfast that can fuel you through a day of hiking? Hardly. That's why our food editor Rhoda Boone created this trio of hot, hearty, make-ahead breakfasts. Wrap them in parchment and foil to create a "hobo pack," toss the packs in the cooler before you hit the road, and throw them on the fire in the morning. You'll have a hot breakfast in minutes, with plenty of time to spare before you check, or, um, *trek* out. 

####Stick to quick-cooking (or precooked) ingredients####

You don't want to wait hours for your breakfast to cook on your campfire, so you need ingredients that cook in just a few minutes. That means using a few pre-cooked ingredients, like sausage links and frozen hash brown shreds. (Another upside to pre-cooked ingredients: They're safer to store in coolers, and you don't have to worry about cooking them perfectly on the campfire.) 

[#recipe: /recipes/55832bc674cbe9ed7c20e492]|||
Breakfast Hobo Packs with Hash Brown Potatoes, Sausage, and Scallions
|||

####Cook, crack in the eggs, cook more####
Even with pre-cooked ingredients (like the canned beans in the Mexican-inspired recipe below), you'll want to cook them together a bit more in the packs before cracking in the eggs. Otherwise, your eggs will be seriously overcooked (and if you want overcooked eggs, stay in that aforementioned hotel!) 

[#recipe: /recipes/55832b5681ac1e5023677fc0]|||
Breakfast Taco Hobo Packs with Black Beans, Zucchini, and Corn
|||

####Finish with a fresh topping####
When you pull your hobo pack open, it'll release a puff of steam. It will smell delicious. Your appetite, sharpened by way too much hiking, will be triggered. You will want to dig right in. But resist the urge (you'll only burn your tongue, after all). Instead, take a moment to shower your eggs with something tasty, like the grated Parmesan and torn basil that you've packed as a garnish for the Italian-style breakfast here. It's just a small thing, but out there in the wilderness, it's the 5-star treatment.

[#recipe: /recipes/55832ad174cbe9ed7c20e488]|||
Breakfast Hobo Packs with Polenta, Prosciutto, and Cherry Tomatoes
|||

section1List.hed: How to Cook a Steak Dinner at the Campfire
section1List.dek: No pots or pans required. (Though you will need a few big rocks.)
section1List.promoHed: Why the Best Way to Cook Steak Is by Campfire
section1List.body:
[#package: /packages/558999be81ac1e502367a00b]|||
Cook It Like a Camper
|||

If there's ever an ideal time to reward yourself with a steakhouse dinner, it's after hiking all day with a 50-pound pack on your back. And yet, so much of camping cuisine revolves around ramen noodles and [dehydrated MREs](http://www.rei.com/c/freeze-dried-dinners?ir=category:freeze-dried-dinners&r=c&page=1)‚Äînot much of a prize after a long trek in the woods.

But it‚Äôs easy to eat like a king (and less like an astronaut), especially when you have a campfire at your disposal. When I camp, I leave my gas-fueled stove and pots and pans at home‚Äîthere‚Äôs nothing worse than doing dishes in the dark‚Äîand do all my cooking in, around, and above the fire. (Hey, if it‚Äôs enough for [Francis Mallmann](http://www.amazon.com/Mallmann-Fire-100-Recipes-Francis/dp/1579655378), it‚Äôs good enough for me.)

And there‚Äôs more to campfire cooking than wienies and marshmallows on a stick. I like to make use of the fire from the moment it‚Äôs lit through the last glowing ember. Using these three techniques and some good ingredients, you can make a tent-side feast that can compete with one cooked in your home kitchen.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55881fa274cbe9ed7c20f037]|||
Start your steaks while the sun sets, and you'll have dessert by nightfall.
|||

+++

####On a Hot Rock####
Without a juicy, caramelized crust, there is no steakhouse steak. Sure, you could get that sizzling exterior by cooking your steak in a cast-iron pan, but who wants to lug one of those on the trail? Instead, steal a trick from fancy restaurants and sear the steak on a hot stone. 

Yes, right on a stone. A large, flat stone or two, heated in your campfire, will cook a steak as well as any cast-iron skillet, with a bonus of wood-smoke flavor. 

The ideal cooking rock is flat, about 2 inches thick, and slightly larger than your cut of meat. (Be careful with any rocks that are porous or have cracks‚Äîwhen heated, they may break apart). To get the rocks hot, build your fire on top of them and let the embers cover them as the fire burns down. Then simply brush them off and throw on the steaks. Alternatively, you can throw a rock or two (it‚Äôs always good to have a spare) on top of the burning logs or hot coals after the fire burns down a bit. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5588542c81ac1e50236790f4]|||
Steak on a Hot Rock with Wild-Herb Butter
|||

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5588199b81ac1e5023678917]|||
Kebabs cooking. All by themselves.
|||

+++

####Around the Fire####
Sure, potatoes are the classic partner for steak, but a plate of fire-singed vegetable kebabs is more colorful (not to mention juicier). And you don't need to roast those kebabs like marshmallows. Instead, take a cue from the Japanese, who like to cook their kebabs vertically in a pile of [*binchotan*](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-buy-charcoal-buying-guide-binchotan-article). It's a great way to utilize a roaring campfire, which usually has to burn down to smoldering coals before it can be used to cook. 

Once my fire is lit, I‚Äôll skewer some marinated vegetables and anchor them in the dirt about six inches away from the flames. Like an upright broiler, the fire will caramelize this Stonehenge of vegetable kebabs in just a few minutes. I usually use smaller ingredients like mushrooms and cherry tomatoes, but this method can be applied to almost anything you can stab onto a skewer‚Äîmeat and fish included.

[#recipe: /recipes/558854a874cbe9ed7c20f25b]||||||

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55881cf381ac1e50236789eb]|||
These ash-roasted sweet potatoes are pretty (and delicious) on the inside.
|||

+++

####In the Coals####
Ash-roasting vegetables may be a favorite technique among the New Nordic chef set, but campers have been doing it forever. By the time you've had your fill of steak and kebabs, your fire will probably have burned down to glowing embers. That's your cue to bury some fruit (apples, peaches, pears) or sweet vegetables (squash, sweet potatoes, etc.) into the ashes; they‚Äôll be ready in time for dessert. Their outsides might blacken and char, but inside they‚Äôll be soft and extra sweet, ready for you to cut them open and dig in (maybe with a couple charred marshmallows and a drizzle of maple syrup on top).

[#recipe: /recipes/5588537d74cbe9ed7c20f247]|||
Ash-Roasted Sweet Potatoes
|||

section2List.hed: How We Turned S'Mores into a Cookie
section2List.dek: Forget about stale graham crackers and unmelted chocolate.
section2List.promoHed: It's True: We Made S'mores Even Better.
section2List.body:
[#package: /packages/558999be81ac1e502367a00b]|||
Cook It Like a Camper
|||

It's almost a law of nature: You can't have a campfire without roasted marshmallows. And you can't have roasted marshmallows without someone wanting to make s'mores.

But it's time for some s'mores real talk. They might be gooey and chocolatey in your memories, but in reality? A s'more is almost never as good as you want it to be. Those boxed graham crackers are usually either too hard, making them hard to bite through, or stale or soggy from time spent in the cooler or someone's car trunk.

And then there's the chocolate. When does that thick piece of bar chocolate ever completely melt? Never. That's when. 

But we were convinced that the childhood s'mores could be transformed into a treat that even the most jaded adult camper would fall for. So we headed into the test kitchen to create S'mores 2.0. 

We were a little ruthless. We nixed the graham crackers altogether. Then we nixed the bar of chocolate. And in place of both, we created a graham-flavored, chocolate-dipped cookie. These things are moist, thanks to a healthy dose of honey and brown sugar; packed with cinnamon-graham flavor; and have a thin chocolate coating that melts perfectly when toasted marshmallows are sandwiched in between them. They freeze beautifully, so you can pack them in the cooler pull them out at the campfire. Or, if you *really* want to break with tradition, you can skip the campfire altogether‚Äîjust roast those marshmallows on a backyard grill and let the sandwiching commence.

Sacrilege? Perhaps. But sometimes you have to roast old traditions to create better ones.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55881ee174cbe9ed7c20ef52]|||
The textbook s'mores cookie moment.
|||

+++

##Create a chewy, graham-cracker-flavored cookie##
Traditional graham crackers are made with graham flour, a coarsely milled whole wheat flour. The ingredient isn't commonly available, so we used a combination of whole wheat and all-purpose flours to mimic the flavor. Using a mix of honey and sugar for the sweetener helped give a graham cracker-like flavor, as did a heaping spoonful of cinnamon. The honey also gave our cookie a nice moist texture, even if you've let them sit for a few days in the refrigerator.

##Add chunks of chocolate##
The first thing Food Editor Rhoda Boone said when we brainstormed ideas for this cookie? "I want it to have chunks of chocolate." Fair enough. Giving our s'mores cookies the chocolate chip treatment tastes as good as it sounds; each bite is packed with chocolate. To add enough chips but keep the sweetness level right, we went with bittersweet rather than the traditional semi.

##Dip Them##
After the problems of stale or too hard graham crackers, our second biggest frustration with traditional s'mores lies in chunk of the chocolate bar, which almost never melts through. In order to solve this, we applied a thin layer of melted chocolate (bittersweet again), to the flat side of each cookie. When the roasted marshmallows meet the cookies, the chocolate instantly melts, creating that luscious texture we always wish we'd get from s'mores of yore.

##Double Up On Marshmallows##
In order to make sure every bite of our sandwich has enough creamy, melted filling, we decided to pack on not one, but *two* roasted marshmallows inside each s'more sandwich. Pro tip: To maximize your 'mallow-toasting efficiency, look for branches with a "Y" shape, which will let you roast four marshmallows at a time, two on each branch. (Maybe even six, if you dare.) Be patient and hold the marshmallows near the edge of the flames to ensure slow and even toasted specimens, not flaming charred ones.

[#recipe: /recipes/5589b6da81ac1e502367a46e]|||
S'mores Sandwich Cookies
|||
section2List.seoTitle: How to Make S'mores Even Better
section2List.seoDescription: Recipe for s'mores cookies for camping (or anytime!).
section2List.socialDescription: Forget about stale graham crackers and unmelted chocolate. This sandwich makes your s'mores dreams come true..

section2List.hed: How to Make a Camp Cocktail
section2List.dek: Because sometimes you get thirsty on the trails. For more than just water.
section2List.promoHed: The Ultimate Portable Cocktail for Summer
section2List.body:
When it comes to boozing in the backwoods, there‚Äôs only one category of libation, in my opinion, that‚Äôs fit for camping: hard liquor. Wine is too bulky for the punch it packs, and beer only makes sense if you‚Äôre car-camping/glamping with ample ice on hand. 

[#package: /packages/558999be81ac1e502367a00b]|||
Cook It Like a Camper
|||

Plus, there are many ways a bottle of hooch‚Äîbe it whiskey, rum or vodka‚Äîcan help you out when you're camping. In fact, liquor is the liquid equivalent of a Swiss Army knife, when you think about it. Here are a just a few more things that booze can do:

1. Local anesthetic: A sip for the pain, a splash for the gash.
2. Mouthwash: Erases morning breath‚Äîand you don‚Äôt have to spit!
3. Fire-starter: Soggy wood can‚Äôt compete with cask-strength hooch.  
4. Insect repellent: If they bite, they‚Äôll fly home drunk.
5. Sleeping aid: This one you already knew.

As such, I always keep a flask of high-proof spirit in my backpack. But recently I‚Äôve become a supporter of flask cocktails for camping as well. These portable drinks‚Äîa favorite among itinerant bartenders‚Äîare designed to be drunk at room temperature or, when camping, the clime of the great outdoors. 

What makes a good flask cocktail? Let‚Äôs start by eliminating anything that contains fresh citrus juice or dairy (save your daiquiris and pi√±a coladas for when you return to civilization‚Äîand freezers). Build your drink around a high-quality spirit, keeping in mind that brown spirits (whiskey, brandy, rum, aged tequila) fare better at room temperature than clear ones (gin, vodka). Next, choose a template: brown spirit-heavy drinks‚Äîsuch [Old Fashioneds](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/old-fashioned-350766), [Sazeracs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sazerac-51193070), [Manhattans](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/manhattan-350780), and the endless variations they spawn‚Äîare a great place to start, as they taste great at almost any temperature. 

##Try something smoky##
You're already cooking your dinner on the campfire. Why not infuse that smoky taste into your camp cocktails, too? A drink with a splash of peaty Scotch will do the trick.

[#recipe: /recipes/5588529b81ac1e50236790e3]|||
Goodnight, Irene Cocktail
|||

##Don‚Äôt forget about water##
For drinks heavy with high-proof spirits, you‚Äôll want to dilute the drink to taste in order to smooth it out (I usually add about 25 percent water, depending on the proof of the base spirit).

[#recipe: /recipes/558852e181ac1e50236790e5]|||
Kumbaya Cocktail
|||


##Load your flask##
When backpacking, I leave my metal flask at home and opt for a lightweight plastic one. Stanley makes [a great one](http://www.llbean.com/llb/shop/80226?productId=1333676&attrValue_0=Navy&mr:trackingCode=42D1E228-2EF3-E211-A497-90E2BA285E75&mr:referralID=NA&mr:device=c&mr:adType=plaonline&mkwid=YhvIVoh8_dc&pcrid=57704150480&qs=3091384_google&product=0NJT120000&cvosrc=cse.google.0NJT120000&cvo_crid=57704150480), as does [Nalgene](http://www.rei.com/product/836469/nalgene-flask-12-fl-oz), but I particularly love cheap disposable flasks [like this one](http://www.disposableflasks.com/). Going on a longer trek? Batch a bunch of drinks in a water bottle and know that the faster you consume it, the lighter your load will be the next day.
section2List.seoTitle: How to Make a Camp Cocktail
section2List.seoDescription: Flask cocktail recipes to take with you when you hit the trails.
section2List.socialTitle: How to Make a Camp Cocktail
section2List.socialDescription: Because sometimes you get thirsty on the trails. For more than just water.

In theory, campfire s'mores are amazing, but the reality is often a stale graham cracker sandwich filled with thick pieces of unmelted chocolate and gooey marshmallows oozing out the sides. This sandwich cookie makes your s'mores dreams come true. The honey and cinnamon-spiked soft cookie is big enough to hold not one, but two toasted marshmallows, and the thin chocolate coating melts perfectly inside.
